supporting.text: Pancreas removal surgery and subsequent lifelong insulin dependency can lead to high medical costs, potentially exceeding insurance coverage limits.

attacks.text: Pancreas removal surgery and subsequent lifelong insulin dependency can lead to high medical costs, potentially exceeding insurance coverage limits.
Many health insurance plans have out-of-pocket maximums that cap annual expenses, preventing financial ruin from high medical costs.
Out-of-pocket maximums may still be prohibitively high for low-income individuals, and some plans exclude certain treatments.
Government assistance programs and patient assistance programs from pharmaceutical companies can help cover insulin costs.
Eligibility for assistance programs is often restrictive, and application processes can be complex and time-consuming.
Bankruptcy is an extreme outcome that requires complete financial mismanagement, not just high medical bills.

supporting.text: Chronic conditions like diabetes mellitus, resulting from pancreas removal, require ongoing expenses for medications, glucose monitoring, and specialist visits.

attacks.text: Chronic conditions like diabetes mellitus, resulting from pancreas removal, require ongoing expenses for medications, glucose monitoring, and specialist visits.
Many health insurance plans cover chronic conditions like diabetes, significantly reducing out-of-pocket expenses for patients.
Insurance coverage may still leave patients with high deductibles, copays, and uncovered treatments, leading to financial strain.
Not all pancreas removals result in diabetes; some patients may retain sufficient pancreatic function or receive islet cell transplants.
Islet cell transplants are expensive and not universally available, and residual pancreatic function is rare post-removal.

supporting.text: Loss of work productivity due to complications from pancreas removal (e.g., frequent hospitalizations) may reduce income and increase financial strain.

attacks.text: Loss of work productivity due to complications from pancreas removal (e.g., frequent hospitalizations) may reduce income and increase financial strain.
Many patients receive disability benefits or insurance coverage that mitigates income loss from medical complications.
Disability benefits often have long approval times and may not cover full lost income, leaving patients financially vulnerable.
Not all pancreas removals lead to severe complications; many patients recover and return to work without long-term financial impact.
Even with recovery, the initial period of lost productivity and medical expenses can create lasting financial strain.

supporting.text: In countries without universal healthcare, out-of-pocket expenses for pancreas-related treatments can deplete savings and lead to debt accumulation.

attacks.text: In countries without universal healthcare, out-of-pocket expenses for pancreas-related treatments can deplete savings and lead to debt accumulation.
Many countries without universal healthcare still have insurance systems that cover major surgeries like pancreas removal, reducing out-of-pocket costs.
Even with insurance, high deductibles and co-pays for pancreas-related treatments can still lead to significant financial strain.
Pancreas removal is a rare procedure, so its financial impact is not representative of broader healthcare costs.
While rare, the high cost of pancreas removal can still be catastrophic for individuals who require it, making the argument relevant.
Financial assistance programs and charity care often exist to help cover the costs of major medical procedures like pancreas removal.
Financial assistance programs are often limited, difficult to qualify for, or insufficient to cover the full cost of treatment.

supporting.text: Insurance denials or high premiums for pre-existing conditions post-pancreas removal can exacerbate financial hardship.

attacks.text: Insurance denials or high premiums for pre-existing conditions post-pancreas removal can exacerbate financial hardship.
Many countries have universal healthcare systems that cover major surgeries like pancreas removal, preventing financial hardship.
Even in countries with universal healthcare, long-term complications or required medications post-surgery may still impose significant out-of-pocket costs.
Employer-sponsored or private insurance plans often cover pre-existing conditions under current regulations, reducing the risk of financial hardship.
Insurance plans may still impose high deductibles, copays, or coverage gaps for specialized post-surgical care, leaving patients vulnerable to financial strain.
